title: 110_s575
content: The Act is titled the "Border Infrastructure and Technology Modernization Act of 2007" and includes definitions for various terms. SEC. 2 of the "Border Infrastructure and Technology Modernization Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Commissioner, Maquiladora, Northern border, Southern border, and Under Secretary. During fiscal years 2008 through 2012, the Under Secretary is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by at least 100 more than the previous year, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by at least 200 more than the previous year. The Under Secretary can waive fte limitations for Homeland Security personnel. Ongoing training is required to ensure proficiency in using new technologies for border protection. SEC. 4. PORT OF ENTRY INFRASTRUCTURE ASSESSMENT STUDY. The Administrator of General Services must update the Port of Entry Infrastructure Assessment Study annually and consult with relevant officials. Each updated study must be submitted to Congress. The Port of Entry Infrastructure Assessment Study must identify projects to enhance border security and facilitate commerce. Projects must align with the National Land Border Security Plan and prioritize based on security needs and trade facilitation. The Commissioner will implement projects in order of priority. The Commissioner can deviate from the priority order if changed circumstances in Mexico or Canada significantly affect the need for a project in the United States, such as immediate security needs or infrastructure changes. SEC. 5. NATIONAL LAND BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Under Secretary must prepare a National Land Border Security Plan by January 31 each year and consult with relevant agencies. The plan should include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with the option to establish port security coordinators. The Under Secretary must prepare a National Land Border Security Plan annually, including a vulnerability assessment of ports of entry on the northern and southern borders. Port security coordinators may be established to assist in conducting the assessment and preparing the required plan. SEC. 6. EXPANSION OF COMMERCE SECURITY PROGRAMS. Expansion of Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism programs along the northern and southern borders, including various industry partnership programs administered by the Commissioner, to enhance security measures. The Commissioner will establish a demonstration program along the southern border to implement a Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism program. Another demonstration program will be established to improve supply chain security. SEC. 7. PORT OF ENTRY TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. The Under Secretary will conduct a technology demonstration program to test and evaluate new port of entry technologies, refine operational concepts, and train personnel under realistic conditions. Technologies tested will enhance port operations, including inspections, communications, tracking, identification of persons and cargo, sensory devices, personal detection, decision support, and detection of weapons of mass destruction. Facilities will be developed at a selected demonstration site for appropriate training to law enforcement. The Under Secretary will establish 3-5 demonstration sites for a program to test new border security technologies and provide training to law enforcement personnel. Sites will be selected based on design, space availability, traffic volume, and ability to incorporate new technologies without disruption. The Under Secretary will establish 3-5 demonstration sites for testing new border security technologies. Selected sites must meet specific criteria, including being established within 15 years, consisting of at least 65 acres with room for expansion, and servicing an average of no more than 50,000 vehicles per month. Additionally, other agencies can utilize these sites to test technologies that enhance port of entry operations. The Under Secretary will establish demonstration sites for testing new border security technologies, including those related to inspections, communications, port tracking, identification of persons and cargo, sensory devices, personal detection, decision support, and detection of weapons of mass destruction. A report must be submitted to Congress annually on activities at each site, with an assessment of incorporating demonstrated technology for wider use within the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection. Authorization of appropriations for border security technology testing and implementation. Authorization of appropriations for border security technology testing and implementation includes funding for various provisions such as carrying out sections 3, 4, and 6 with specific allocations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 and beyond. Authorization of appropriations for border security technology testing and implementation includes funding for specific provisions for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 and beyond, with allocations for technology demonstration projects and subsection (b) activities. This includes $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $5,000,000 for the demonstration project, $5,000,000 for subsection (b) in 2008, and $50,000,000 for section 7 in 2008. Authorization of appropriations for border security technology testing and implementation includes funding for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 and beyond, with allocations for projects related to the Border Partnership Action Plan and Smart Border Declaration between the United States and Mexico, as well as Canada.
